awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  REU Site: Multisite REU in Synthetic Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative REU site award to Simmons University, located in Boston, MA, and North Carolina A&T State University, located in Greensboro, NC, will support the training of 12 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019- 2021. This is a multisite REU collaborative and each site will host 6 students each summer. The focus of the program is to provide research experiences in the multidisciplinary field of Synthetic Biology, an emerging field of biology that integrates multiple scientific disciplines, including biology, mathematics, chemistry, and computer science.  Faculty mentors will be drawn from the Departments of Chemistry, Biology, Mathematics, and Computer Science at both institutions. During the 10-week program, students will be engaged in synthetic biology research projects that teach them how to 1) use synthetic biology strategies to solve complex biological problems, 2) work in a multidisciplinary research team, and 3) develop cross-disciplinary communication skills. A common week-long boot camp will be incorporated at both institutions using shared modules to articulate common objectives, laboratory techniques, and computational skills.  To foster the collaboration between the sites, paired virtual research groups will be created between sites and joint programming in STEM career planning will be delivered using a variety of social media platforms. The online learning community will consist of weekly cohort meetings via webinar and a virtual journal club led by students and facilitated by faculty mentors. During the program, students will also participate in a series of workshops focused on core synthetic biology techniques, bioethical issues associated with synthetic biology, implicit bias and sexual harassment in STEM, and careers in STEM. The summer program will culminate with a consortium-wide virtual symposium where students will have the opportunity to present their research to their colleagues and receive constructive feedback.  Students will be selected based on their interest in research, academic record, recommendation letters from their home institutions and phone interviews with faculty mentors on the selection committee. 

It is anticipated that a total of 36 students, primarily from underrepresented minority groups and from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program.  Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences.  This program is designed for students interested in pursuing research careers in STEM fields. 

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program.  Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting or by contacting the PI (Dr. Jennifer Roecklein-Canfield at Jennifer.canfield@simmons.edu)  or the co-PI (Dr. Mariam Ismail at Mariam.ismail@simmons.edu) at Simmons University or the PI (Dr. Robert Newman at rhnewman@ncat.edu) at North Carolina A&T State University.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the previous project period, we successfully launched our Multisite REU in Synthetic Biology. The program, which provided integrated synthetic biology research experiences for a total of fifty-two (52) undergraduate students at Simmons and NC A&T, has been particularly effective at mentoring underrepresented minority students (Figs. 1 & 2, Table 1). For instance, the percentage of participants from underrepresented minority groups was above 70% each year of the program. In particular, the percentage of African American (AA) students in the program has increased steadily each year, increasing from 42% in the first year of the program to 69% and 61% in 2022 and 2023, respectively. Likewise, first generation college students were well represented in our cohorts, peaking at 50% in 2021 and never falling below 33% throughout the program. Our success in the first 3 years of the project period was rewarded with an Accomplishment-based Renewal in 2023. Upon receiving this funding, we were able to maintain the same demographic distribution of participants. The collaborative efforts have seen 35 (NCAT) and 21 (Simmons) conference presentations at regional and national Science meetings and 12 contributing authors in scholastic journal manuscripts published or in preparation. 

During their projects, the students learned and applied synthetic biology strategies such as DNA cloning, PCR, gene editing, and computational modeling. This is supported by responses in the SALG-URSSA survey. For instance, across all cohorts, 81% of the participants indicated that the program greatly enhanced their engagement with real-world science research (with a mean Likert score of 4.8/5.0 in the category). Similarly, students were able to make strong connections between theory and practice, as indicated by mean gains of 4.7/5.0 across all cohorts in “understanding the theory and concepts guiding [their] research project”. Likewise, the program helped to dramatically increase students’ scientific self-efficacy, where students reported mean gains of 4.6/5.0 in response to the questions: “how much did you feel a part of the scientific community” and “how much did you feel responsible for the project”. Similarly, students across all cohorts indicated that they had grown substantially in “[their] ability to contribute to science” (mean gain of 4.6/5.0).

Another important goal of the project was to establish a model for collaborative, multisite REUs. To this end, REU students at NC A&T and Simmons University participated in a series of virtual workshops, a virtual journal club, and virtual lab meetings to discuss their projects. The virtual sessions were conducted via the Zoom platform. The meetings created opportunities for collaboration across programs. For instance, during the virtual lab meetings, students from NC A&T or Simmons presented a short overview of their respective projects and provided research updates. Both students and PIs participated in the meetings, asking questions about experimental methods and offering advice pertaining to technical difficulties that the students were encountering with their projects.  Many of these activities were student-led, increasing the sense of ownership of their work and addressing gaps in a sense of belonging in science.  The effectiveness of this interdisciplinary approach is reflected in student responses to several questions in the SALG-URSSA survey related to collaboration and interdisciplinary thinking. For instance, students across all cohorts reported mean gains of 4.7/5.0 in the category “Understanding connections among scientific disciplines” and gains of 4.8/5.0 and 4.6/5.0, respectively, in the categories of “Comfort in working collaboratively with others” and “Making connections between disciplines”.

In summary, during the project, we provided integrated research opportunities in synthetic biology for twenty-six (52) undergraduate students. Of the twenty-six (26) hosted at Simmons, twenty (20) were from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM. Among the twenty-four (24) students who have graduated, eleven (11) continued onto graduate school, with eight (8) students (33%) pursuing MS/PhDs and the remaining 3 (11%) pursuing Postbaccalaureate degrees. Likewise, three (3) REU students are currently enrolled in medical/dental school while nine (9) students are currently in careers in the bioscience workforce. By providing research experiences for undergraduate students, a large proportion of whom are from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM, our program has helped increase the diversity of the STEM workforce and contributed new knowledge to the field of Synthetic Biology.
